item.title: Israel arrests two Palestinians who carried out shooting attacks in the West Bank
item.description: The two Hamas linked operatives were involved in shooting incidents earlier this month, targeting Israeli cars near Hawara and an attack on the Jewish settlement of Carmel
item.dc:creator: Haaretz

item.title: Next Israel army chief may find his biggest mission lies within IDF ranks
item.description: Former lawmaker and journalist Ofer Shelah, now a senior researcher at the INSS, has written an extensive research on the state of the IDF's personnel and ground forces. He suggests a far-reaching overhaul while not overlooking the changes needed in the very ethos
item.dc:creator: Amos Harel

item.title: With Ukraine on the offensive, 'sham referendum' held in Russian-occupied territories
item.description: Russia is expected to justify the annexation of four regions via the 'referendum,' and with Putin's announcement of a draft to enlist 300,000 troops to fight in Ukraine, Moscow seems to be trying to regain the upper hand
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: When Lapid talks about two-state solution, he isn’t talking to Mahmoud Abbas
item.description: Reindorsing the two-state solution, the Israeli PM sought to win left-wing votes, but even if he wins the election he'll have to form a coalition with MKs who oppose a Palestinian state ◾ Netanyahu has created an alternative Likud, another significant milestone in the transformation of the party to a one-man, one-family movement
item.dc:creator: Yossi Verter

item.title: Former Pakistani minister: Israeli support for two-states can be ‘deal clincher’ for ties
item.description: A Pakistani delegation that visited Israel this week is the latest sign of potential for warming ties between the two countries. One former minister said progress on the Palestinian front would make a big difference
item.dc:creator: Judy Maltz

item.title: Is the West taking Putin's nuclear threats too lightly?
item.description: Prof. Dima Adamsky from Reichman University thinks that the probability of Putin using nuclear weapons is still low. But he is concerned by what he calls 'a strategic destabilization of the Russian nuclear systems'
item.dc:creator: Amos Harel

item.title: Hezbollah threats, West Bank tensions: Clouds gather as Israel prepares for fall holidays
item.description: 'The main difficulty is foiling all the attempted terror attacks on time,' warns a senior officer as the army prepares to boost forces along West Bank roads
item.dc:creator: Amos Harel

item.title: The police commissioner is right, blame the internet administrator
item.dc:creator: Hanin Majadli

item.title: Israel's inflation-busting ministers should be 'Men of the Year'
item.dc:creator: Nehemia Shtrasler

item.title: Alleged Nazi sympathizer gets four years in prison over U.S. Capitol attack
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Television poll gives Netanyahu bloc a 61-seat majority
item.description: According to Channel 13's poll, the current coalition is predicted to win 55 seats. The poll further shows Netanyahu's Likud party receiving 32 seats and Prime Minister Yair Lapid's Yesh Atid party earning 25
item.dc:creator: Haaretz

item.title: Israeli Prime Minister Yair Lapid's full UN speech
item.description: In his first address to the General Assembly in New York, Lapid reiterated his support for the two-state solution
item.dc:creator: Haaretz

item.title: Ministry walks back demand for external educators to pledge to uphold Nakba Law
item.description: New wording applies criteria only to content of programs offered by outside providers, not the educators themselves
item.dc:creator: Shira Kadari-Ovadia

item.title: Wayi and Uri would never meet today
item.dc:creator: Lea Forshtat

item.title: 'The Israel I see today is not the Israel I moved to in the '70s'
item.description: This week at the Tel Aviv airport: Two American expats who moved to Israel for different ideological reasons, and two friends who had an experience of a lifetime volunteering at a commune in the Arava desert
item.dc:creator: Danna Frank

item.title: The just-not-Bibi camp needs Bibi
item.dc:creator: Carolina Landsmann

item.title: The news is that there is no news
item.dc:creator: Haaretz Editorial

item.title: Haaretz Cartoon
item.dc:creator: Eran Wolkowski

item.title: Praise, condemnation after Lapid reaffirms commitment to two-state solution
item.description: Biden welcomes 'courageous statement' from Israeli leader, but former PM Netanyahu accuses Lapid of opening the door to 'a terror state'
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lis

item.title: 'My father took part in the '36 Berlin Olympics. He wanted Jews to prove the Nazis wrong'
item.description: Kurt Epstein was a champion swimmer and water-polo player who represented Czechoslovakia in two Olympiads, one of them in Berlin in 1936, but after the Holocaust and communism, he was forgotten in his homeland. Recently, his daughter decided to commemorate his life, centering an exhibition around his century-old tallit
item.dc:creator: Helen Epstein

item.title: Israel's Arab voters can decide it all. Do they want to? LISTEN to Election Overdose
item.description: After the fallout in the Joint List, what's next for Arab voters in Israel ahead of the November 1 election? And also, what did we learn from Lapid's speech at the United Nations this week?
item.dc:creator: Election Overdose

item.title: Israel's borders like you've never seen them before
item.description: ‘Natural Settings’ is a work in progress by Haaretz photoblog editor and photographer Daniel Tchetchik. In it, he travels to Israel’s borders in search of human nature
item.dc:creator: Avshalom Halutz

item.title: Eight wounded in terror attack in central Israel, assailant shot dead
item.description: According to eyewitnesses, the Palestinian assailant carried a knife and pepper spray and tried to open the doors of cars standing at an intersection in central Israel, before being shot dead by an off-duty police officer
item.dc:creator: Josh Breiner

item.title: Morocco’s economy is sinking, but its king prefers the bright lights of Paris
item.description: The country has been spending millions of dollars on military hardware but still hasn’t recovered from the effects of a serious drought and the COVID pandemic. Youth unemployment is soaring, along with rental prices and public outrage
item.dc:creator: Zvi Bar'el

item.title: More than fish: Sea of Galilee's top 20 restaurants
item.description: Haaretz headed north to Lake Kinneret, and returned with delicious recommendations
item.dc:creator: Gil Gutkin

item.title: The tragedy of queer Palestinians, now on stage
item.description: Many LGBTQ Palestinians flee the West Bank to Israel to escape persecution, but for most, it’s no solution. A new play is based on one of many such painful stories
item.dc:creator: Sheren Falah Saab

item.title: Israeli Prime Minister Lapid touts two-state solution at UN
item.description: Lapid calls on Palestinians to 'build a future together, both in Gaza and the West Bank' ■ Warns Iran will use nuclear weapons if it gets them and urges 'a credible military threat on the table'
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lis

item.title: Lapid's two-state endorsement is meaningless, except in one scenario
item.description: In Israel’s current political reality, Lapid’s endorsement of two states is meaningless ■ Democrats slam Rashida Tlaib for saying Israel supporters can't be progressive ■ Iran's 'hijab war' won't diminish its anti-Western identity ■ Today’s best reads on Haaretz
item.dc:creator: Amir Tibon

item.title: A brief history of prehistoric art and why Israel doesn't have any
item.description: From a hominin scratching on a clam half a million years ago to Neanderthals spraying ocher, art is hard to define. So far, sapiens is the only figurative artist in history. Why is another matter
item.dc:creator: Ruth Schuster

item.title: Israel expands number of work permits for Gazans
item.description: Defense Ministry decides to allow 17,000 Gazans to work in Israel in order to maintain stability in the region, in continuation of a policy that will see the number increase to 20,000
item.dc:creator: Hagar Shezaf

item.title: UAE to buy Israeli air defense tech in first deal since accords, sources say
item.description: Israel and the U.S.-allied UAE share an ultimate fear, that Iran obtains a nuclear weapon, an ambition Tehran denies
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Eden has the freshest voice in Israel
item.description: On her second album, ‘Holy Triangle,’ Eden Derso does something very few Israeli rappers can do
item.dc:creator: Ben Shalev

item.title: Why Iran won't save Netanyahu
item.description: Netanyahu's Iran policy was a disaster for Israel's national security, poisoned relations with U.S. Jews and the Democrats and failed at the ballot box. But ahead of November's elections, his opponents are making a similar mistake
item.dc:creator: Dahlia Scheindlin

item.title: When your art can travel to your exhibition but you can't
item.description: The impossible lives of African asylum seeker artists in Israel. 'Whenever these thoughts are getting to me, I paint and it calms me'
item.dc:creator: Vered Lee

item.title: U.S. Jewish groups team up to promote election integrity this November
item.description: The Jewish Partnership for Democracy comes as a national security forum says religious leaders will have a key role to play during and after the midterms
item.dc:creator: Ben Samuels

item.title: The female photographer who captured Palestinian lives 100 years ago
item.description: In the early 20th century, Karimeh Abbud photographed the landscapes and people of her homeland. A new exhibition provides an opportunity to learn about her importance in documenting Palestinian lives
item.dc:creator: Ofer Aderet

item.title: Through their eyes: A new look at Israel's fringes
item.description: Roba Alfraowna challenges how Bedouin are seen ■ Eden Zornitser captures gender fluidity ■ Saja Quttaineh roams around East Jerusalem ■ Asaf Shaked revisits Kiryat Gat ■ Avshalom Halutz speaks with seven up-and-coming photographers
item.dc:creator: Avshalom Halutz

item.title: New York's ultra-Orthodox schools: A story of big money, lobbyists and political power
item.description: An unusual alliance of political powerbrokers, private schools and lobbyists have sold out New York's ultra-Orthodox children for decades, denying them a basic education. Now, despite the outcry, they’re doing it again
item.dc:creator: David C. Bloomfield

item.title: Israeli official slams police chief's call to shut down social media during civic unrest
item.description: After Israel's police chief touted the benefits of censoring social media during periods of civil unrest for the second time, Public Security Minister Omer Bar-Lev denounces the 'unfortunate statement'
item.dc:creator: Josh Breiner

item.title: Democrats slam Rashida Tlaib for saying Israel supporters can't be progressive
item.description: Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz is among those to criticize Rep. Tlaib, saying that her ‘outrageous progressive litmus test’ on Israel is ‘nothing short of antisemitic’
item.dc:creator: Ben Samuels

item.title: Shireen Abu Akleh's family turns to International Criminal Court to demand investigation
item.description: A coalition of Palestinian lawyers and advocacy groups have referred the fatal shooting of Al Jazeera journalist Shireen Abu Akleh to the International Criminal Court. This comes only weeks after Israel acknowledged that it likely bears some responsibility for the killing of the beloved Palestinian journalist
item.dc:creator: Jack Khoury

item.title: Israeli embassy vandalized during Mexico City protest over 43 abducted students
item.description: Relatives of the 43 disappeared students, known as the Ayotzinapa 43, and supporters protested outside the Israeli embassy in Mexico City to demand the extradition of former state investigator Tomas Zerón; Israeli ambassador: 'writing death to Israel on the embassy's walls has nothing to do with the case'
item.dc:creator: Haaretz

item.title: 'Israel is a radical country. Either you take action, or you become bitter'
item.description: Working on the fringes, often for free and without institutional backing, these artists and curators are not bitter about reality. They’re establishing their own places. Meet the disruptors of the Israeli art world
item.dc:creator: Joy Bernard

item.title: Palestinian accused of assaulting Israeli settler released by court on Thursday
item.description: Hafez Huraini was arrested last week on suspicion of aggravated assault on an Israeli, but the military Court said on Thursday that the evidence revealed a 'complicated picture' after a 23-minute video showed the settler approaching Huraini with guns and clubs
item.dc:creator: Hagar Shezaf

item.title: Israeli police fire gas grenades in Palestinian neighborhood for no apparent reason
item.description: In a video published Wednesday on Palestinian networks, the two policemen are seen standing in a square in the West Bank town, without any clear threat nearby, not in the road nor beyond the separation fence
item.dc:creator: Jack Khoury

item.title: Struggling with high prices? Israel’s national shopping spree says otherwise
item.description: Whatever your friends, newspaper headlines and politicians say, there’s no sign that the high cost of living in Israel really bothers many people
item.dc:creator: David Rosenberg

item.title: Israel Police chief backs officer who shot disabled Palestinian man
item.description: 'What was done cannot be undone" Police Chief Kobi Shabtai said at a ceremony, adding that the Israel police 'accept no deviation from the organization's values' but that they must stand by the officer 'even under these circumstances'
item.dc:creator: Josh Breiner

item.title: Palestinian arrested after crashing through security barrier at Israel's airport
item.description: An initial investigation revealed that on Thursday night, a Palestinian resident of the Ramallah area in his thirties arrived at the airport gate with a vehicle he had stolen from a Tel Aviv suburb
item.dc:creator: Ran Shimoni

item.title: U.K. could move embassy to Jerusalem, Truss tells Lapid
item.description: British prime minister says the government is 'reviewing current location of embassy in Israel'
item.dc:creator: Haaretz

item.title: Panicking over military call-up, young Russian men scramble to leave country
item.description: Social media has been overflowing with Russians panicking over the draft, with flights filling up and ticket prices soaring as draft-age men flee Russia
item.dc:creator: Liza Rozovsky

item.title: Bulldozers demolish permitted Bedouin protest tents erected against housing shortage
item.description: Police denied having approved the protest tents, erected in opposition to the plan to relocate hundreds of Bedouins from nearby unrecognized village to the city of Rahat. But documents signed by officials from the Rahat police station show that the protest was in fact approved
item.dc:creator: Nati Yefet

item.title: With the uprising in Nablus, the Palestinian Authority's fall becomes a palpable threat
item.description: The clashes showed that bolstering the PA isn’t merely an Israeli security interest, but above all a Palestinian interest. Palestinians don’t want a vacuum of governance; they want a functioning PA that will protect them and tend to civil affairs
item.dc:creator: Jack Khoury

item.title: Is this mixed Jewish-Arab city the future of Israel?

item.title: Israel indicts Islamic Jihad leader whose arrest sparked latest Gaza conflict
